description: From Middle English dysy, desy, dusi, from Old English dysiġ (“stupid, foolish”), from Proto-West Germanic *dusīg (“stunned; dazed”), likely from the root of Proto-Germanic *dwēsaz (“foolish, stupid”).
Akin to West Frisian dize (“fog”), Dutch deusig, duizig (“dizzy”), duizelig (“dizzy”), German dösig (“sleepy; stupid”).

entries.meaning: Experiencing a sensation of whirling and of being giddy, unbalanced, or lightheaded.
examples: I stood up too fast and felt dizzy.
We climbed to a dizzy height.
My new secretary is a dizzy blonde.
Them as diz ’at is dizzy.Those who do that are half-witted.

verbs.description: dizzy (third-person singular simple present dizzies, present participle dizzying, simple past and past participle dizzied)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To make (someone or something) dizzy; to bewilder.
(slang, automotive) A distributor (device in internal combustion engine).
examples: A service exchange distributor usually needs to be ordered by a motor factor and cost £150-200! I would suggest you use the SD1 dizzy body/cap etc but change the trigger mechanism to a modern electronic/breakerless unit such as the Newtronic unit.
